Situation1: Their parents directly open up about a personal struggle and look to them for comfort.
Expectation2: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation2: Management closely monitors break logs because the phone queue remains consistently full.
Story: The phone rings again, and I glance at the clock—my scheduled break is in two minutes. My headset feels heavy, and my supervisor’s words echo in my mind: “Don’t go over your break time. We’re watching the logs.” I’m about to log out when my stepdad’s name flashes on my phone. I hesitate, but answer. His voice is shaky, and he tells me Mom’s been having a hard time lately, and he doesn’t know how to help her. He needs me to listen, to be there, to say something comforting. I hear the pain in his voice, and I know he’s reaching out because he trusts me. But my break is ticking away, and if I’m late, I’ll get another warning. I want to be the stepchild they can lean on, but I also need this job. My heart pounds as I try to split my attention, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, knowing I can’t give either what they truly need from me in this moment.
